question: Question_06_(a)
statement:
Let \emph{u} be a unit vector and \emph{Q = I - 2uu\textsuperscript{T}}.
Show:

\textbf{(a)} The matrix \emph{Q} is symmetric and orthogonal.
sols:
First, we can show that the matrix \emph{Q} is symmetric by showing that
\emph{Q=Q\textsuperscript{T}}:

\[\displaystyle Q^T=(I-2uu^T)^T=I^T-(2uu^T)^T=I-2(u^T)^Tu^T=I-2uu^T=Q\]

Next, we can show the matrix \emph{Q} is orthogonal by showing that
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{T}Q=I}. Since we know that \emph{Q} is
symmetric, \emph{Q\textsuperscript{T}Q=QQ}.

\begin{align*}
Q^TQ &= (I-2uu^T)(I-2uu^T) = I-4uu^T+4(uu^T)(uu^T)\\
&= I-4uu^T+4u(u^Tu)u^T
\end{align*}

Notice that \emph{u\textsuperscript{T}u} is just a number. In fact,
$u^Tu=\|u\|^2$ and since $u$ is unit vector $\|u\|^2=1$. Thus, indeed
\emph{Q} is orthonogal:

\[\displaystyle Q^TQ=I-4uu^T+4u(1)u^T=I-4uu^T+4uu^T=I.\]
hints:
To show that \emph{Q} is symmetric, confirm that
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{T} = Q}. Remember that
\emph{(ab)\textsuperscript{T} =
b\textsuperscript{T}a\textsuperscript{T}}.

To show that \emph{Q} is orthogonal, confirm that
\emph{Q\textsuperscript{T}Q = I}. Use that \emph{u\textsuperscript{T}u =
\textbar{}\textbar{}u\textbar{}\textbar{}\textsuperscript{2}} and that
\emph{u} is a unit vector.
